channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s Big Policy Bill Puts U.S. on Perilous Fiscal Path
item.description: Among the most expensive pieces of legislation in years, the Republican bill could reshape the country’s finances for a generation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: As Debt Piles Up, Countries See Fiscal Relief as Political Leverage
item.description: With developing nations crushed by unaffordable borrowing and Washington on the sidelines, some leaders are brokering debt forgiveness deals.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump’s Threat of More Tariffs Slows Trade Deals
item.description: As America’s largest trading partners race toward deals, they are increasingly worried about being hit with future tariffs on their critical industries.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Signals U.S. Is Nearing Trade Deals but Says Some Countries Will Face Tariffs
item.description: President Trump said the United States would send out letters telling other countries “what they have to pay,” even as other officials said negotiations could be extended past a July deadline.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Some Republicans Join Democrats in Unease Over White House Budget Cuts
item.description: President Trump has sought to claw back funds for public broadcasting and foreign aid, sparking a fierce debate over the power of the purse.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: How Yemeni Cafes like Haraz Coffee House Are Building Momentum and Community
item.description: For cafes like Haraz Coffee House, riding a wave of interest nationwide in late-night, alcohol-free gathering spaces means embracing the franchise model.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Barber

item.title: Trump Confronts Potential for High Oil Prices After Iran Strikes
item.description: President Trump, aware of how high gas prices could affect his popularity, demanded on social media that the U.S. “KEEP OIL PRICES DOWN.”
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: No Rock Stars, No Mercedes: A Russian Expo Shows the Cost of Divorce With the West
item.description: The annual economic forum in St. Petersburg used to yield multibillion-dollar deals and feature performances by global music stars. With the war in Ukraine still raging, the mood has shifted.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: How Trump’s Trade War Has Whipsawed the Port of L.A.
item.description: The nation’s largest ports, in Los Angeles County, are a bellwether for the economy. They are being whipsawed as President Trump reorders global trade.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Mark Abramson

item.title: House Policy Bill Would Add $3.4 Trillion to Debt, Swamping Economic Gains
item.description: The updated findings from the Congressional Budget Office amounted to the latest dour report card for the president’s signature legislation.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Companies Ask Supreme Court to Fast-Track Challenge to Tariffs
item.description: Two toy manufacturers asked the court to greatly expedite their case, in an unusual request.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak

item.title: Senate Republicans Propose Key Tax Tweaks to House Bill
item.description: Party lawmakers proposed changes to the tax code that could offer the greatest benefit to businesses.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Fed’s ‘Wait and See’ Approach Is Intact as New Risks Cloud Economic Outlook
item.description: The central bank is set to hold interest rates steady for its fourth straight meeting, a pause that could be extended through the summer.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: As Trump Returns to G7, Rift With Allies Is Even Deeper
item.description: In 2018, the president called for the group to embrace Russia and stormed out of the summit. Now he is seeking to shrink America’s military role abroad and embarking on a more expansive trade war.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: ‘Golden Share’ in U.S. Steel Gives Trump Extraordinary Control
item.description: Administration officials secured a deal that will give the president unusual influence over a private company, and could serve as a model for other deals.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Lauren Hirsch

item.title: Trump Steel Tariffs Expand to Hit Home Appliances Like Refrigerators and Dishwashers
item.description: The move is one of the first times this year that consumer products were specifically targeted with higher import taxes.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport

item.title: Where’s the Inflation From Tariffs? Just Wait, Economists Say.
item.description: Are predictions for a jump in consumer prices too early, or just wrong?
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: How Labor Unions Came to Define the L.A. Immigration Protests
item.description: Unions have backed immigrant rights in California and have been on the forefront of resisting the Trump administration’s deportations.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: New China Trade ‘Deal’ Takes U.S. Back to Where It Started
item.description: If a handshake agreement holds, it will merely undo some of the damage from the trade war that President Trump started.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: U.S. Court Agrees to Keep Trump Tariffs Intact as Appeal Gets Underway
item.description: The appeals court’s decision delivered an important but interim victory for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
